Black Desert Online is one of the most visually stunning and immersive MMORPGs available today. The game stands out with its fluid, action-based combat system, offering deep, satisfying gameplay where every class feels unique. The world is massive, alive, and full of activities—grinding, trading, life-skills, exploration, PvP, world bosses, and a complex in-game economy that keeps you engaged for the long run.
Character customization is unmatched, allowing you to create incredibly detailed and unique avatars. The game receives frequent updates, has a strong community, and offers complete freedom in how you choose to play.
If you want a modern, dynamic, and visually breathtaking MMO with endless content and a truly immersive world, Black Desert Online is absolutely worth your time. Highly recommended.

The game, though I hate to say it, really is quite good once you move past the rough new player experience. But, even to a new player, it's clear the current direction of the game is less than ideal. In essence, they are incentivizing AFK players too much and not incentivizing active playtime enough. Is that a good direction for a living online world? Well, you can decide.

The other main problem is the monetization. If Pearl Abyss ever needs more money, they could just make a new, really cool skin. Infinite USD potential. That's real money, too, not whatever funny money Korea uses. They even... used to do that, I think, seeing as some of the skins already in the game are quite cool. Currently, however, they favor creating new P2W items instead. The game has enough paid "convenience" items, it doesn't need more. PA, trust me: you could make more money just by making cool skins and being more generous with your playerbase.

But yeah, the game is quite good. I get the sense it used to feel even better, though, when it had less AFK fishing and less pearl shop items.

I'll leave the review positive, for now, since I don't think there's a better MMO available on the market (save for maybe GW2), but I hope PA addresses the AFK meta and focuses more on skins and less on costumes and pets.

Black Desert is a massively multiplayer online role-playing game (MMORPG) developed and published by Pearl Abyss. It focuses on action-oriented combat, deep character customization, and an open-world sandbox design.

Gameplay emphasizes real-time combat rather than traditional tab targeting. Players use manual aiming, combos, and movement similar to an action game. Each class has distinct mechanics and fluid animations, rewarding skill and timing over automated combat systems.

Beyond fighting, the game features extensive life-simulation systems. Players can fish, trade, cook, craft, farm, breed horses, or manage workers across cities. These non-combat systems integrate into the economy, giving players multiple paths to progress.

The open world is seamless—no loading screens between regions. It features cities, deserts, forests, and oceans populated by NPCs with schedules and personalities. Dynamic weather, day-night cycles, and a detailed node system create a living environment.

Visually, Black Desert is one of the most graphically advanced MMOs available. The character creator is exceptionally detailed, allowing near-limitless customization. Environments and lighting are realistic, supported by smooth animations and particle effects.

Sound design enhances immersion through orchestral music, ambient nature sounds, and dynamic combat audio. Voice acting varies by region but complements the tone of each storyline.

Overall, Black Desert offers a vast, visually stunning MMO experience focused on freedom, skill-based combat, and player-driven progression. Its depth and complexity appeal to dedicated players seeking a long-term, immersive world rather than casual, guided play.

I highly recommend this game.  It's a Korean MMO so the game world is beautiful, character models are great and the game is full of complex systems (big plus for me as an older MMO player).  The combat is very fun and cinematic...if you're into the Soulcalibur style.  The combo system in combat gives a lot of depth and really rewards skilled gameplay.

However, I do strongly advise players not to play this game like a sprint to the finish.  I don't think that's possible, or if it is you sacrifice your life and/or bank account to do so.  This is a game that's meant to be played slowly, taking the time to explore different systems in depth and really learn the intricacies of how to optimize your class.

If you enjoy that, then this an amazing game.  If you want the instant-gratification of quickly obtaining top-tier gear and jumping into the toughest content...this is not for you.  Also, there is very much a cash shop.  I personally don't feel the need to spend more than the $40 I already have, but if you want to sweat-lord the game then you probably will want to spend (a lot) more.

As a long-time veteran of this game, I still enjoy it and continue to play, but I cannot recommend it to new players.

The game has steadily shifted away from meaningful PvP. It is no longer rewarding and actively penalizes players for engaging in it. Despite being marketed as an MMO, it functions more like a solo experience, with almost no substantial group content. Even at endgame, PvE group activities amount to at most a couple of hours per week. In the past, PvP helped fill this gap, but that is no longer the case.

There are many additional issues, but the core problem is the developers’ complete disregard for player feedback. Even when an overwhelming majority of the playerbase is unified in their criticism, it is consistently ignored. Meaningful action only seems to happen when backlash becomes so severe that it directly impacts their revenue. Each year they issue apologies for their so-called mistakes, yet the same patterns continue with no real change or accountability.

For these reasons, I do not recommend purchasing this game, even if it is free, and I would advise extreme caution regarding their upcoming title, Crimson Desert.

Returning player from 2017 tried it again just for fun to see where it was at and it’s mixed feelings.

The progression is fun up till around 740’sh GS. To get any type of upgrade beyond that is the most time consuming slog ever. You either swipe the credit card to melt costumes for crons to enhance. Or you literally grind for 10 hours a day to buy vendor crons with silver to enhance. You can save your silver and buy pen Debo to exchange for NOV Khara but no new player is going to do that. It’s a big time drain and it will burn you out if you think you can handle grinding for thousands and thousands of hours. I tried it, got burnt. Realized I will be doing this forever, then gave up. Because there’s no point when PVP is dead. More than half the player base is AFK fishing in Velia. And there’s hardly any group content to do with friends. It’s a lonely MMO and some people love that and some find it very boring. The combat is fun and the animations and detail put into the classes is awesome. But beyond that the game is in crying state. And will continue to lose players to OSRS if it doesn’t fix its path.

As a long-time veteran of this game, I still enjoy it and continue to play, but I cannot recommend it to new players.

The game has steadily shifted away from meaningful PvP. It is no longer rewarding and actively penalizes players for engaging in it. Despite being marketed as an MMO, it functions more like a solo experience, with almost no substantial group content. Even at endgame, PvE group activities amount to at most a couple of hours per week. In the past, PvP helped fill this gap, but that is no longer the case.

There are many additional issues, but the core problem is the developers’ complete disregard for player feedback. Even when an overwhelming majority of the playerbase is unified in their criticism, it is consistently ignored. Meaningful action only seems to happen when backlash becomes so severe that it directly impacts their revenue. Each year they issue apologies for their so-called mistakes, yet the same patterns continue with no real change or accountability.

For these reasons, I do not recommend purchasing this game, even if it is free, and I would advise extreme caution regarding their upcoming title, Crimson Desert.

Returning player from 2017 tried it again just for fun to see where it was at and it’s mixed feelings.

The progression is fun up till around 740’sh GS. To get any type of upgrade beyond that is the most time consuming slog ever. You either swipe the credit card to melt costumes for crons to enhance. Or you literally grind for 10 hours a day to buy vendor crons with silver to enhance. You can save your silver and buy pen Debo to exchange for NOV Khara but no new player is going to do that. It’s a big time drain and it will burn you out if you think you can handle grinding for thousands and thousands of hours. I tried it, got burnt. Realized I will be doing this forever, then gave up. Because there’s no point when PVP is dead. More than half the player base is AFK fishing in Velia. And there’s hardly any group content to do with friends. It’s a lonely MMO and some people love that and some find it very boring. The combat is fun and the animations and detail put into the classes is awesome. But beyond that the game is in crying state. And will continue to lose players to OSRS if it doesn’t fix its path.

TLDR: Heavy PTW, hardly any content, fun combat, cool outfits, crappy dev team.
